bioghist.p: Princess Marie Louise, of the British Royal Family, conceived of the idea of creating a Dolls' House for Queen Mary (Consort of King George V). She asked Sir Edwin Lutyens to design it and contacted numerous authors and artists to create original miniature books and paintings for the Dolls' House. Rudyard Kipling wrote his "If" in miniature specially for that purpose. Intended also as a showcase for British craftsmanship, the dollhouse was originally exhibited at the British Empire Exhibition in 1924. It is on permanent display at Windsor Castle.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of letters relating to the production of miniature paintings, drawings, etchings, and texts for miniature volumes for Queen Mary's Dolls' House. The letters accompanied submissions for consideration by Princess Marie Louise; some of the more famous artists and authors writing to the princess include Bernard Partridge, Margaret Kemp Welch, Cecil Aldin, W. Heath Robinson, A. E. Houseman, Henry Holiday, W. Russell Flint, Adrian Stokes, and Marjorie Bowen. Drawings and paintings are not included in this collection.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
